Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Middle Pleistocene Hominin Behavior and Paleoecology at Farre, Chalbi Basin, Northern Kenya

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The African early Middle Pleistocene saw the emergence of archaic Homo, the expansion of hominin brain capacities to near-modern dimensions, and the first appearance of a battery of sophisticated new technologies. And yet, as relatively few African localities sample this important timeframe (i.e. the period from c.781-500ka), the specific details regarding the timing, setting, and dynamics that underlie the emergence and early evolution of these advances remain poorly understood. With an estimated minimum age of c.600-500ka, recent paleoanthropological discoveries at the open-air site of Farre, located in the Chalbi Basin of northern Kenya, may add important new data relevant to these issues. In this project, an interdisciplinary team of investigators will conduct a two-year archaeological and geochronological study to better understand the age and contents of the Farre site. Broader impacts of the project include the opportunity to build research collaborations across universities, museums, and research centers, research and training opportunities for students and junior faculty, and public education and conservation outreach at the field site and in the U.S.

During two seasons of paleoanthropological fieldwork at Farre, the investigators will expand preliminary excavations to further document the presence of in situ archaeological materials, increase the sample size of diagnostic artifact forms and fossil taxa, refine the geoarchaeology and paleoenvironmental setting of the site; and refine the geochronology of site. Finds from preliminary excavations include artifacts consistent with both Early and Middle Stone Age technologies, coupled with fossil taxa suggesting an age in excess of 500ka. Farre may thus help bridge a long-standing gap in the record of this paleoanthropologically-important region, refine our understanding of the emergence and early evolution of important technological capacities, and place inferred hominin adaptations within local, regional, and global paleoenvironmental contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

This project determined the timing and analyzed the paleoenvironment and hominin behavior of a Middle Pleistocene archaeological site, Farre (GfJo2), in the Chalbi Basin of northern Kenya. The Middle Pleistocene marked the advent of modern homo sapiens and was thus an important time in the context of hominin evolution. Farre is unique in that there are few archaeological sites in East Africa that document Middle Pleistocene archaeology. Investigating the paleoenvironment and paleoclimate context of Farre advanced our understanding of Middle Pleistocene archaeological sites and processes that alter them after occupation.

Our collaborated research team, which included archaeologists, paleoanthropologists and Earth scientists from around the world, made significant advances in determining the age and paleoenvironment of Farre. Faunal analysis of the Farre assemblage was consistent with a ~500 ka age; however, numerical dating methods yielded later Middle and Late Pleistocene ages. These younger numerical ages documented the timing of weathering, e.g., grain mixing and soil carbonate precipitation, and thus recorded evidence of a series of weathering episodes overprinting the archaeological site. Paleoenvironmental data, e.g., C and O stable isotopes, paleosol geochemistry, and fauna, suggested periods of wetter condition or more hydroclimatic variability in the past. Several of these paleoenvironmental proxies may post-date the site occupation and thus yield paleoclimate data not directly tied to the hominin activitites. This latter point indicates that open-air archaeological sites in East Africa may be exposed to multiple past climates and environments, complicating the paleoenvironmental interpretations.

Broader Impacts:

Aspects of this project benefited the local Kargi community in northern Kenya by providing work opportunities for both women and men. This project provided training and professional development opportunities for two undergraduate students, both of which were first-generation college students participating in the Murray State University McNair Scholar Program. Both of those students are now pursuing M.S. degrees in Earth sciences. These students were featured in University-wide press releases, which showcased some aspects of their Farre-related research. A postdoctoral scholar, a visiting scholar and an early-career investigator also benefited from this project through learning how to analyze and manage soil and paleosol data.
